description: Number of flat partitions of n: partitions {a_i} with each |a_i-a_{i-1}| <= 1.
comments: Also number of partitions of n such that all parts, with the possible exception of the largest, appear only once. Example: a(6)=7 because we have [6], [5,1], [4,2], [3,3], [3,2,1], [2,2,2] and [1,1,1,1,1,1] ([4,1,1], [3,1,1,1], [2,2,1,1], [2,1,1,1,1,1] do not qualify). - _Emeric Deutsch_ and _Vladeta Jovovic_, Feb 23 2006Also the number of partitions p of n such that d(p) > max(p) - min(p), where d is the number of distinct parts of p; indeed that inequality occurs only when d(p) = 1+ max(p) - min(p), so p satisfies a(i) - a(i-1) = 1 for all parts, ordered as a(i) >= a(i-1) > ... a(k). - _Clark Kimberling_, Apr 18 2014
